items.description: Cuckmere River
items.message: The Cuckmere River through Alfriston remains high following Friday's rain, but is now falling. Flood impacts will continue to affect fields, gardens and roads including North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. The Bull River through Hellingly has fallen further, but is still higher than normal and minor impacts will continue to affect Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. The Cuckmere River through Hellingly has already returned nearer to normal. Saturday will be mostly dry, allowing the rivers to fall, returning to normal by Saturday afternoon in Hellingly and by Sunday afternoon in Alfriston. More rain is forecast on Sunday evening into Monday 30/09/2024. A month's worth of rain may fall within 24 hours, which will increase flood risk and make property flooding possible. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road Hellingly and North Street Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 15:00 on 29/09/2024.

items.description: Combe Haven
items.message: The Powdermill Stream in Crowhurst has fallen significantly since Friday. Only minimal flood impacts, with small amounts of water, are expected to be affecting fields. Saturday (28/09/2024) will be mostly dry, which will allow river levels to continue to fall, returning to normal in Crowhurst from midday on Saturday. In Bulverhythe, river levels will fall much slower, and could remain higher than normal through the weekend. More rain is forecast on Sunday evening (29/09/2024) into Monday (30/09/2024). Potentially a month's worth of rain may fall within 24 hours, which will increase flood risk and make property flooding possible. Flood protection products are recommended to be kept installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 15:00 on 29/09/2024.

Further flooding is possible today, as river levels are falling but remain higher than usual. Further heavy rain is forecast for Sunday and levels will rise again in response. We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further Flood Alerts or Warnings as necessary.

Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 29/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely this morning, Saturday 28th August, and throughout the next 24 hours. Water levels are expected to continue to rise gradually over the next few hours. The forecast high tide at Great Yarmouth will restrict the Broads river system from draining out to sea which, combined with recent rainfall, is resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Sunday 29th September, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Eastern Yar
items.message: The water level in the Eastern Yar is higher than normal. In the last 5 days more than a monthâ€™s rain (72mm) has been recorded at Wroxall. Until 12:00 today (Saturday 28/09/2024), at Sandown, minor impact flooding could affect Golf Links and Moreton Common Road. Property flooding is not expected. Today (Saturday 28/09/2024), the weather will remain dry, and water levels will lower at Sandown by early afternoon. On Sunday (29/09/2024) and Monday (30/09/2024), further heavy rain is forecast with up to 40mm expected. If this volume of rain does affect the river, then there will be much more widespread impacts to low lying land, footpaths, cycle tracks and roads in both the upper and lower river. We have checked that the Bembridge sluice is operating normally. We continue to monitor the forecast and will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure that any products used to protect gardens or property from flooding can operate if required over the next 2 to 3 days. This Flood Alert will be updated by 10:00 on Monday 30/09/2024.

items.description: Lower Welland

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Welland, Old River Welland, Maxey Cut

items.message: Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the Lower Welland area. This means that the River Welland has risen, which will lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't currently likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 17:00 on 28/09/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Buscot Wick down to Shifford
items.message:
This flood warning has been removed. 

River levels on the Thames have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of property flooding from the river, though standing water and debris may still remain. Saturday is expected to be dry with rain likely on Sunday. River levels are expected to continue falling but remain sensitive to further rainfall. We are monitoring river levels and will re-issue this warning if required. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Areas near the River Nene from Elton to Wansford
items.message: Heavy rain fell in the Nene catchment earlier this week and Thursday evening, which has caused the River Nene to rise. Low lying areas near the river are flooded and we now expect properties in London Road, Wansford and Mill Lane, Water View, Marina Terrace in Yarwell to continue to be affected today,  Friday 27 September 2024. No further rainfall is expected today and into tomorrow, Saturday 28 September 2024, however, river levels are expected to remain high. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. Please avoid contact with flood water. Our staff are out in the area to check the flood defences, clear blockages, and assist the emergency services and council. We will be closely monitoring the situation, and this message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 17:00 on 28/09/24, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Uck
items.message: The River Uck has fallen significantly since Friday. Saturday (28/09/2024) will be mostly dry and the river will continue to slowly fall, which will allow any minor flood impacts to further ease. More rain is forecast on Sunday evening (29/09/2024) into Monday (30/09/2024). Potentially a month's worth of rain may fall within 24 hours, which will increase flood risk and make property flooding possible. As a precaution, flood protection products are recommended to be kept installed in Buxted and Isfield, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 15:00 on 29/09/2024.

items.description: River Avon at Stanford on Avon

items.message: The River Ouse has peaked in York below levels of significant concern. This flood warning has been removed as the risk of flooding to properties is no longer expected. River levels will remain high and a flood alert remains in place. Avoid low-lying footpaths and roads which may still be affected by flooding. Floodgates along the riverside paths remain closed where required.

items.description: River Ouse at Naburn Lock

Avoid low-lying footpaths and roads which may still be affected by flooding.

items.description: River Avon at Evesham
items.message:
River levels remain high but steady at the Evesham river gauge because of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland continues.  We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in the Waterside Road area as well as the car park on the meadow.  

Predicted peak: - Evesham 2.75m to 2.9m this morning, 28/09/24.    

No further rain is forecast today.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and refer to flood plan for information.   

This message will be updated by 5pm on Saturday 28/09/24, or as the situation changes.
